comments.commentBody:
We the people enable this hypocrisy. Instead of ""Tinker to Evers to Chance," it's taxpayers to CEO's to politicians......

And the money goes round and round.

Your tax rates are disingenuous. The people in those countries don't pay 6-13% in state income tax, nor do they pay $20K a year in property tax on their houses. You have to look across the total tax burden from all jurisdictions. The 19.2% of GDP figure looks low, but it is only the Federal share.

As for spending, you have to throw away money numbers and look at reality. This is the amount of actual goods and services produced and consumed. Would more goods and services be produced if the government printed and handed out money? Do we have vast reserves of additional people who could do useful work? If we define useful work as producing an output worth more than what they are paid, the answer is probably no. So that puts us in the position of the USSR tableware factory that produced spoons and forks worth less than the raw materials it used. We would be destroying wealth, not creating it.

That depends on how you define the rich, doesn't it? If you take the top 10%, that's 13 million households with incomes greater than $120K. Since they control a lot of important institutions, such as the government and the financial system, the chance of getting a significant amount of their money is small.

If, on the other hand, you just pick on the billionaires, you will discover it is impossible to raise significant sums of money. There are just too few of them for it to be worthwhile.

There are a large variety of people who don't work for various reasons, but could work. You can hardly say that all 100 million people between 16 and 64 who don't have jobs are sleeping under bridges. Many of them live quite comfortably.

Sanders' proposed programs would probably add to their number to some degree. However, the chance of any of these programs being enacted is nugatory.
Maybe "everyone" can do it, but "everyone" cannot do it simultaneously. It is not possible for everyone to run a trade surplus -- my trade surplus has t be someone else's trade deficit.

'Maybe "everyone" can do it, but "everyone" cannot do it simultaneously'
But everybody can try to do it - as it is definitely better to run a surplus than not. And that is not even the main point. The main point is that if a country doesn't have a well balanced economical structure with the right amount of manufacturing plus Finance plus Service plus high Tech such an economy is not sustainable AND - probably the most important fact - doesn't have enough well paying jobs to make the people happy!

Don't see Switzerland as a good example.  They've always had a high currency, were panicked when it was decontrolled, still worried, have lost exports.  Further, most large Swiss companies are multi-national in the sense that their income comes from outside.  As another writer said ... everyone can't export their way out of their problems, a fantasy world ... as China is finding out.

I live in an export dependent country (New Zealand) where the $NZ falls in times of economic adversity as investors put their $US/Euros/Yen in safe havens. So a loss in exports of firms due to reduced sales to overseas customers is compensated for somewhat by increased per unit revenue in $NZ terms.

Having that cushion gives NZ firms breathing space to adjust costs or rejig their product mix in order to survive.

On the other side of the coin a fall in the NZ dollar makes life more difficult for importers and means imported goods are more expensive.

A variable dollar gives New Zealand the time and flexibility it needs to adapt as circumstances change. If we were part of another country's currency bloc we would lose this important buffer feature.

The point made by some commenters that Germany is able to export high value goods and so everyone else should as well - for a start Germany entered the Eurozone when it had low input costs relative to it's past. So in those terms it has a permanently low currency to export in.

When Italy or France cannot devalue, their firms don't get the same time to adjust that NZ firms do with their flexible currency.

If you have an export culture then when trade barriers are removed you can do well. If you are a culture/nation that has traditionally relied on your own consumers for sales, then open trade means firms take a lot longer to adapt or they fold. Without a variable exchange rate to help, often the pressure is too much, too soon.
sk:  You accuse atheists of  arrogance and expect them to beg forgiveness?  Still silly or ignorant, or most likely just failing to understand.
Agreed. Maybe not the exact usage referred to in the article, but close. I specifically recall a woman I worked with over 20 years ago saying "it's a guy thing" or "it's a sports thing."
Yes, it's been around for at least 60 years or so.  I've been aware of this usage for as long as I can remember (born 1953, grew up in the Northeast in a family from NYC).

I'm sure the described use of the term "a thing" has been around for at least two or three decades.  Maybe a typical doctoral candidate is too young and inexperienced to know that or to draw correct conclusions.
And a sari covers parts of asia? Sounds more like deliberate obfuscation than a clue.
RMP - and I saw MEATLOAF. Wondered what the sauce was.

.
Good points, Viv.

It also occurred to me that the difficulty of recent crosswords may have given Elke a case of the vapors. Besides, I imagine she is diligently attending to the removal of BREAD from their home. She could also be absorbed in watching video of her Prime Minister explaining various aspects of quantum theory.

Last, I would not be surprised if the tenor of the US presidential race has led any of our Friendly Neighbors to the North to relocate to underground shelters for seven months (or for 4 years, seven months). In their shoes, I would be quite wary of our electoral outcome. It's bad enough for them that Vladimir Putin lurks not far away; but if a deranged person were to occupy the top US office, things could get worse.

Earlier today I was musing happily that we vote tomorrow so we only have one more day of TV ads before the candidates head off for other pastures.  Then it struck me:  I have not received a single flyer or postcard or anything else touting a candidate in the mail!  Email, yes.  Tons of it.  But nothing in the postal mail.  Considering that whole forests have been destroyed in efforts to sway my vote for such things as Judge of the Surrogate Court, this is truly astonishing.  And welcome.

We haven't heard from Robert/Elke in a few days. I wonder if they've traveled somewhere to celebrate his 80th birthday, coming up Wednesday. I know they prefer to avoid announcing when they'll be away from home. Anyway, I hope they're reading us wherever they are.

That "some languages (such as the amalgam that has become "English") are better than others in encouraging nuance and richness of variety" is completely untrue. The need for nuance and richness of variety in linguistic expression is so deeply ingrained into the human mind that any spoken language offers roughly the same breadth of possible expressions with all the subtlety and nuance that is required.

Funnily enough, speakers of languages with a richer morphology than English (German, French, Russian, Arabic - the list is endless, since English is especially lacking in overt morphologiocal markers) often (wrongly) cite English as being a "poor" language since it does not allow for the subtle shifts in meaning that can be accomplished with grammatical markers or reordering of words.

That is of course, not true. Languages achieve their variety and richness in different ways - where Russian, for example, encodes aspect and modality with grammatical markers, English often has to resort to using whole phrases (or tense) to express the syntactic concept of aspect for a given verb.

What you're saying would imply that speakers of some languages cannot express the emotional, social and intellectual richness of their lives and culture as much as speakers of English can. That is an offensive and somewhat imperialist point of view that has no basis in reality and is not borne out by linguistic research.

in reply to MattW:

Not all languages are equal and not just in the ability to express nuance. Think, for instance, of Yiddish, a language that developed by largely persecuted people to hide their true meaning from the "others." Elements such as indirection, inflection, and reversal become essential parts of the language to facilitate communication among "us" while shielding true meaning from "them."

William the Conqueror in 1066 brought French into Old English, greatly expanding the soon-to-become common tongue on the Island. In addition, English is much more of a decriptive language than is French which, because of the cultural authority of the Acadamie Francaise, leans toward the prescriptive.

And then there is what a thing is not, as ruminated on in his song, "(This Ain't) No Thinkin' Thing", by Trace Adkins:

"This ain't no thinkin` thing, right brain, left brain
It goes a little deeper than that
It's a chemical, physical, emotional devotion
Passion that we can't hold back
There's nothin` that we need to analyze
There ain't no rhyme or reason why
'Cause this ain't, this ain't no thinkin` thing."

That said, "thing", as referenced by the author, Alexander Stern, has become another touchstone of the inarticulate and obfuscatory, as are the ubiquitous acceptance of oxymorons, such as "virtual reality", as well as disingenuous and tendentious euphemisms, such as "collateral damage" (for civilian casualties) and "right-to-life" (for anti-abortion.)

Language is dynamic and is legitimately considered both descriptive and prescriptive. However, some languages (such as the amalgam that has become "English") are better than others in encouraging nuance and richness of variety. However, for that to occur there must be a general consensus that change should reflect an increase rather than a decrease in description, categorization, and understanding in general.

Hi, Viv, I MADE meatloaf tonight! You are right, once I carve the meatloaf, it could look just like the honey walnut bread. Here it is in the pan:

http://shodor.org/~rpanoff/meatloaf17apr.jpg

Philosophy, is pronounced in far too many places, with no small measure of disregard. Imaginably, even from the dawn of philosophy, there may have been those who've disregarded developed thought, projected through lengthy, convoluted sentences, appearing irrelevant to the here and now.
Though admittedly drawn to philosophy, at times leaning upon it, the well written article on "Is That Even a Thing" aids me in understanding all those whose lips curl up and brows bunch over critical, when anyone waxes philosophical.
Please take this not as a critique, for I am not nearly in the position of passing criticism on any doctoral candidate in philosophy rather, I would hope, that this thing that we're doing here, this repartee of sorts, would draw attention to the need for the interjection of philosophical thought in our daily lives, our private lives and the way we live as a community, locally and globally.
While at very deep meaningful levels, the understanding of how we have come to use the term "thing" might unlock heretofore hidden expanses of neurology and the "behavior" of our thought, there remain other areas of existential relevance that philosophy may contribute to.
Philosophers, see the relevance of you're studies. Share it with us lip-curled, bunched-brow skeptics, one sentence at a time, then maybe "things" will be a bit nicer for all.

What a supreme shame! Everything all over again. Just like 64. Once more with feeling.Welcome Chevron, Hi FMI, Howdy Goldman Sachs, dig,dig,dig right in! Thanks, "market"! Thanks, São Paulo. Nice job.
According to recent polls, she has the support of 8% of the population. That's as close as possible to everyone "wanting her out."

The article is very tendentious. Paulo Sotero said: "people want her out". Unfortunately he does not specify what kind of people want her out. Also to define the worker's party as "band of leftist agitators" is oversimplify the history of a political party that was fundamental in the struggle against the dictator regime. We expect NYTimes for all the credibility that it has to have a more sophisticated analysis.

This decision is so unfair and sexist.  Women, like, you know, should have every opportunity to corrupt and embezzle as much as they like.  Men would never be treated so harshly.  Brazil, join the 21st century, quick.

This is disgusting. Today they vote to determine if pedaling tax is corruption, and is't. Our votes are now on trash, 54 milions of people go vote and now that was't valid in a night of disrespect to us. The true is: 200 of 500 congress was investigated of us justice, what we see is the bourgeoisie want to take off an
government that made public university, social programs and take off the misery milions of brazilians. Today they open an window to Eduardo Cunha, powerful leader of the lower house, SCAPE of his crimes. We dont want that. They are accomplices of Jair Bolsonaro, an man who cited the torturer of Dilma at the military dictatorship, an man who supports who hates the LGBT comunity, who supports who are racist. We dont want that to us.
What about the upcoming summer Olympics that are to be held in Brazil? Will the facilities be ready? How will security measures be sufficient in a nation in chaos?

Political football is pretty good in Brazil. Hope your next president will prop up the stock market by a 1,000 times. Stock holders are more important to please than the working poor. Heck, whoever can sustain a bull market has no need to buy votes from the poor.

Brazil is following constitutional democratic rules in order to proceed democratically to impeach our President , Ms. Dilma Vana Rousseff.
We are observing strictly the procedures of our constitutional law. Nothing else.
Every kind of speculations regarding a " coup" represents an attack against the Brazilian democracy and its people.
The impeachment move against Ms. Rousseff of Brazil is based on accusations of budgetary manipulation involving the use of funds from state banks to cover budget gaps. In Brazil it is a serious constitutional crime.

As positive a step as I believe this *might* be if it's followed-up with 80 or 90 years of house-cleaning in Brazil's legislature, judiciary and electoral system...

... it's really nothing but a faster version of the USA's own implosion, which will take *centuries* to fix once it finally makes the news like Brazil's version has today.

They should have done it to Bush for his stupidity in Iraq and the 08 disaster but Americans foolishly let him go. Wake up Americans the world is showing you up on how to tackle corruption I hope Americans can turn away from Kardishans for a second  and wake up and realize their govt is robbing them blind.
Sometimes we think we have it so bad with our own political situation, we forget how bad some things are in other countries.

I am Brazilian , and I am very disappointed by the direction the country has taken . Brazilian media promoted the coup and people were easily influenced . I liked the way you expose the facts.hopefully in Brazil were so.

I am Brazilian , and I am very disappointed by the direction the country has taken . Brazilian media promoted the coup and people were easily influenced . I liked the way you expose the facts. Hopefully in Brazil were so.

The populist government of Brazil since 2002 took possession of the wealth produced by economic restructuring and distributed to the poor as a way to "buy" votes, and institutionalized a major corruption scheme. That was the biggest blow to the Brazilian demoracia.
